metadata.title: Decoding Circulating Neutrophil Phenotypes in Triple-Negative Breast Cancer via Optimized Single Cell RNA Sequencing
metadata.description:
Neutrophils are emerging as key regulators of tumor biology, influencing cancer progression, immune evasion, and therapeutic response. However, their transcriptomic characterization remains challenging due to low RNA content, limiting confident discrimination from other leukocyte populations at the single-cell level. To address this, we developed a robust analytical framework for single-cell RNA-seq data, calculating a neutrophil score for each cell based on two curated neutrophil marker gene panels and excluding cells expressing non-neutrophil marker genes.  

White blood cells were isolated from liquid biopsies of 9 breast cancer patients (3 luminal B and 6 triple-negative) and 6 non-malignant donors, sequenced, and analyzed to profile 84 neutrophils from triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) and 128 control neutrophils. TNBC neutrophils displayed significant upregulation of migration-associated genes (–log₁₀ adjusted p ≈ 3) and respiratory complex genes (p < 1 × 10⁻⁹) compared with controls. Furthermore, TNBC and luminal breast cancer neutrophils shared highly similar transcriptomic profiles, both clearly distinct from those of healthy donors.  

These findings demonstrate that breast cancer induces a shared transcriptional reprogramming of circulating neutrophils across subtypes, suggesting systemic immune modulation linked to tumor presence. This work provides a validated framework for precise neutrophil identification and functional characterization in single-cell studies and lays the foundation for dissecting their mechanistic roles in cancer progression.

data.title: Decoding Circulating Neutrophil Phenotypes in Triple-Negative Breast Cancer via Optimized Single Cell RNA Sequencing

metadata.title: Comparative Supply Chain Risk Management for Biologics and Pharmaceuticals (messenger RNA (mRNA) vaccines and gene therapies): FDA, Health Canada, and EMA Approaches
metadata.description: This study examines the comparative Supply Chain Risk Management (SCRM) frameworks applied to biologics and pharmaceuticals, specifically messenger RNA (mRNA) vaccines and gene therapies, across the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA), Health Canada, and the European Medicines Agency (EMA). Biologics and advanced therapies present unique manufacturing and distribution challenges due to their complexity, sensitivity to environmental conditions, and reliance on high-integrity cold-chain systems. Using a comparative case study methodology supported by Failure Mode and Effects Analysis (FMEA), this research evaluates how regulatory agencies manage risks related to production, quality assurance, and distribution. Findings indicate that harmonized risk management practices grounded in International Council for Harmonisation (ICH) Q9 (Quality Risk Management) and Q10 (Pharmaceutical Quality System) principles can reduce supply disruptions by approximately 30% and improve compliance outcomes. The study highlights the growing emphasis on data integrity, Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP) compliance, and cross-border cooperation, especially under emergency pathways such as the FDA’s Emergency Use Authorization (EUA) and EMA’s accelerated approval.

data.title: Comparative Supply Chain Risk Management for Biologics and Pharmaceuticals (messenger RNA (mRNA) vaccines and gene therapies): FDA, Health Canada, and EMA Approaches

metadata.title: A Critical Re-evaluation of "An ATP-gated molecular switch orchestrates human messenger RNA export" by Hohmann., Nature 2025; doi: 10.1038/s41586-025-09832-z
metadata.description:
This deposit provides a comprehensive, multi-dimensional, and rigorously structured critique of the 2025 Nature article “An ATP-gated molecular switch orchestrates human messenger RNA export” by Hohmann, Graf, Tirian, Pacheco-Fiallos, Schellhaas, Fin and colleagues. The critique evaluates the study from structural, biochemical, cellular, statistical, computational, conceptual, and evolutionary perspectives, offering the most extensive independent post-publication assessment of the proposed mechanism to date.

The original paper introduces an ambitious model in which the DEAD-box helicase DDX39 is positioned as an ATP-gated molecular switch sequentially directing TREX loading, TREX release, TREX-2 engagement, and nuclear pore targeting for virtually all human mRNA transcripts. Because this mechanism implies a fundamental reorganization of long-standing paradigms in mRNA export biology, its evidentiary and conceptual robustness warrant exceptionally thorough scrutiny.

This commentary presents a full figure-by-figure and extended-data–by–extended-data analysis, demonstrating that the proposed mechanism is not supported by the data shown in the publication. Structural differences between ATP- and ADP-bound states are extremely subtle and lack the conformational magnitude required for a switch-like model. Biochemical assays lack reproducibility, quantification, and appropriate controls. Imaging analyses lack raw data, standardized acquisition, and statistical evaluation. RNA-sequencing results show minimal transcriptomic effects inconsistent with disruption of a universal export determinant. Extended Data Figures reveal internal inconsistencies, insufficient replicates, and contradictory phenotypes.

Beyond the empirical shortcomings, the critique evaluates the biological plausibility of the model. The proposed mechanism conflicts with established roles of TREX, TREX-2, NXF1, Dbp5, Gle1, nucleocytoplasmic directionality checkpoints, mRNP heterogeneity, nuclear spatial organization, and evolutionary conservation across eukaryotes. It additionally fails key energetic, architectural, and phenotypic plausibility tests.

Together, these analyses show that the central claim of an ATP-gated master switch for mRNA export is incompatible with known principles of RNA biology and lacks the evidentiary foundation necessary for acceptance. The commentary aims to support scientific transparency, strengthen post-publication peer review, and encourage rigorous methodological standards for mechanism-level claims affecting core processes of gene expression.

The deposit includes the full structured commentary, with numbered sections, detailed textual analysis, and systematic evaluation of all figures and supplementary materials. It is intended as a resource for researchers in RNA biology, structural biology, gene expression, and scientific integrity.
keywords: mRNA export, DDX39, ATP-gated switch, TREX complex, TREX-2, nuclear pore complex, RNA helicase, gene expression, nucleocytoplasmic transport, post-publication peer review, structural biology, RNA sequencing, RNA biology, export mechanism, critique

data.title: A Critical Re-evaluation of "An ATP-gated molecular switch orchestrates human messenger RNA export" by Hohmann., Nature 2025; doi: 10.1038/s41586-025-09832-z

metadata.title: A Critical Re-evaluation of "MAPK-driven epithelial cell plasticity drives colorectal cancer therapeutic resistance" by White et al., Nature 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09916-w
metadata.description:
This comprehensive commentary provides a systematic, multidimensional critique of the paper “MAPK-driven epithelial cell plasticity drives colorectal cancer therapeutic resistance” by White, Mills, Millett et al., published in Nature (2025). The original study proposes a high-impact mechanistic model in which MAPK pathway reactivation drives dynamic epithelial identity transitions that underpin drug resistance in colorectal cancer. Because this claim challenges well-established principles of intestinal epithelial biology, clonal evolution, cancer lineage fidelity and therapeutic resistance mechanisms, the evidence must satisfy exceptionally rigorous standards. This commentary evaluates the study’s conceptual, methodological, computational and biological foundations across twelve structured sections, including detailed figure-by-figure critiques, in-depth analysis of Extended Data and Supplementary Figures, assessment of biological plausibility, and thorough evaluation of data integrity and reproducibility.

The commentary demonstrates that the study’s central claim is not supported by the presented evidence. Key methodological weaknesses include inadequate validation of markers used to define putative plasticity states, unstable clustering and trajectory inference based on single-cell RNA sequencing, insufficient genetic perturbation controls, underpowered proteomic datasets, qualitative rather than quantitative imaging, and limited in vivo replication. The computational pipelines lack transparency, raw data are not accessible, and crucial parameters are missing, preventing independent verification. The biological model conflicts with established principles of intestinal epithelial lineage stability, MAPK signaling biology, and clinical patterns of resistance, and the study presents no chromatin-level, transcription factor-level, or functional lineage-tracing data necessary to demonstrate bona fide identity transitions.

Alternative explanations—including transient stress responses, dissociation artifacts, metabolic fluctuations, microenvironmental heterogeneity and clonal selection—more plausibly account for the observed transcriptional variation. The study’s interpretation overextends high-dimensional data structures into unwarranted biological conclusions and employs conceptual definitions of “plasticity” that shift across analyses. Despite the volume of data presented, no consistent mechanistic chain links MAPK modulation to durable lineage transformation, nor does the study establish relevance in patient-derived specimens.

This commentary provides a rigorous, integrated evaluation that clarifies why the MAPK-driven epithelial plasticity model cannot be accepted as a mechanistically or biologically validated explanation for therapeutic resistance in colorectal cancer. It also outlines methodological and conceptual standards required for future research to meaningfully advance the field.
keywords: Colorectal cancer, MAPK signaling, epithelial plasticity, therapeutic resistance, single-cell RNA sequencing, trajectory inference, lineage fidelity, clonal selection, proteomics, chromatin biology, cancer biology, reproducibility, data integrity

data.title: A Critical Re-evaluation of "MAPK-driven epithelial cell plasticity drives colorectal cancer therapeutic resistance" by White et al., Nature 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09916-w

metadata.title: A Critical Re-evaluation of "RNA innate immunity constitutes a barrier for interspecies chimerism" by Hu et al., Cell 2025; doi:10.1016/j.cell.2025.10.039
metadata.description:
This work presents a comprehensive critical commentary and systematic re-evaluation of the study “RNA innate immunity constitutes a barrier for interspecies chimerism” by Hu, Sun, Sakurai, et al., published in Cell (2025). The original article proposed a mechanistic model in which xenogeneic pluripotent stem cell (PSC)–derived RNA is sensed by host embryos through RIG-I–like receptor pathways, triggering antiviral innate immune activation that restricts donor-cell survival and thereby limits cross-species chimerism. Because the claims of this study have broad conceptual and translational implications—spanning developmental biology, immunology, synthetic embryology, and organoid-based xenogeneic chimera generation—rigorous post-publication scrutiny is essential.

This commentary provides a structured, section-by-section reassessment of the entire study, including conceptual framing, methodological execution, experimental design, statistical rigor, computational analysis, biological plausibility, and reproducibility. A dedicated figure-by-figure critique evaluates all main Figures 1–7, Extended Data Figures 1–15, and all Supplementary Figures. Particular attention is paid to issues of species-resolved transcriptomics, RNA structural immunogenicity, RLR pathway competence in preimplantation embryos, PSC culture-state heterogeneity, and the biological plausibility of antiviral signaling in early development.

The analysis identifies several major weaknesses that collectively undermine the central claims of the original paper:

  1. lack of species-resolved mapping or lineage tracing, preventing unambiguous attribution of innate immune activation to host versus donor cells;
  2. absence of biochemical assays demonstrating direct RIG-I/MDA5 engagement with donor RNA;
  3. insufficient controls for RNA purity, dsRNA specificity, and transfection artefacts;
  4. incomplete validation of CRISPR knockouts and limited chimerism rescue magnitudes;
  5. highly variable and weak imaging signals, small sample sizes, and inconsistent quantification;
  6. computational analyses that conflate transcriptomic divergence with immunogenic potential; and
  7. biological implausibility of strong innate immune responses at preimplantation stages.

Taken together, our integrated synthesis concludes that the evidence provided in the original study does not convincingly support the assertion that RNA innate immunity forms a major barrier to interspecies chimerism. This commentary aims to enhance transparency, stimulate methodological rigor, and provide a framework for future investigations into the true mechanistic constraints governing xenogeneic chimera formation.
keywords: interspecies chimerism, pluripotent stem cells, innate immunity, RNA sensing, RIG-I, MDA5, MAVS, dsRNA, embryo development, xenogeneic barriers, transcriptomics, RNA editing, ADAR1, PSC stress responses, cell competition, developmental incompatibility, immunology, RNA biology, chimeric embryos, post-publication review

data.title: A Critical Re-evaluation of "RNA innate immunity constitutes a barrier for interspecies chimerism" by Hu et al., Cell 2025; doi:10.1016/j.cell.2025.10.039

metadata.title: Trichodina koloti Jager, Basson & Marwijk, 2019, sp. nov.
metadata.description:
Type species: Trichodina koloti sp. nov.

Type locality and type host: Sclerophrys gutteralis (Power, 1923), Nxamasere Floodplain, Okavango panhandle, Botswana (S 18° 35, 770’ E 22° 01, 551’)

Additional locality and host: Sclerophrys powerii (Hewitt, 1926), Nxamasere Floodplain, Okavango panhandle, Botswana (S 18° 34, 984’ E 22° 00, 035’)

Type-specimens: Holotype, slide 2016/12/15-01 and paratype, slides 2015/07/09-01 and 2015/07/12-09

18S nucleotide accession number: MT214940

Etymology: koloti (noun); [Tswana, a language spoken in southern Africa and the Okavango Delta region] – meaning tadpole

Morphology and morphometrics

Adult trichodinid specimens collected from tadpoles had a C-shaped macronucleus with a mean external diameter of 31.1–57.4 µm (47.0±9.5), thickness of 4.5–11.3 µm (7.2±2.5) and length of sector between terminations of macronucleus 3.8–38.5 µm (21.1±13.7) with no micronucleus were observed (Fig. 2). The adoral spiral followed a course of 370°–405°, which falls within the variation for the genus Trichodina. Based on the comparative morphological dimensions of all six populations, with only the minimum and maximum values given, the trichodinids had a convex body diameter ranging from 43.5–62.6 µm; adhesive disc diameter between 37.3–51.2 µm with a poorly to welldeveloped border membrane with a width of 2.7–5.7 µm (Table 5). The denticle ring diameter is between 21.3–35.3 µm, consisting of 20–28 denticles and 8–13 radial pins per denticle. The denticle blades are strong, semi-circular with a prominent apophysis on the anterior side with a length from 4.3–7.1 µm, tapering off towards a pointing tip. The ray of the denticle is strong, generally straight and tapers off towards the tip, it has a length ranging from 4.5–7.4 µm. The central part width is from 1.2–2.7 µm and the total denticle span is between 5.9–16.0 µm. There is little to no biometric variation between trichodinids collected from the different pools and anuran hosts, also not for seasonality (Figs 3–9).

By analysing the denticle dimensions for the Botswanan tadpole ecto trichodinids, according to the van As and Basson (1989) method (Figs 10a–f): The blade region was the most constant with minor differences between the specimens examined. Almost all had large, broad blades filling a large part of the section between the y and y+1 axes with the tangent point being slightly more proximal than the distal blade margin. The distal blade margin (surface) was generally curved, gradually sloping towards the proximal direction and parallel to the border membrane. Most of the posterior blade margins (surface) were smoothly curved in a shallow L-shape, with a few exceptions that were more deeply curved. In all the specimens the deepest point of the curve was more proximal than the apex of the blade, although some were almost on the same plain. The apexes of the blades were generally rounded, with some being slightly more pointed, and most of them extended past the y+1 axis. The anterior blade apophysis had slightly varying degrees of prominence, with the majority of specimens being somewhat prominent. No posterior projections on any specimens were observed. The central parts were slender and elongated. The distal surface was smaller, sloping more than the proximal. For the majority of the specimens the central part extended halfway past or more than halfway to the y axes. The form of the ray was mostly delicate.Almost all rays were of straight and equal width for the whole length, ending in a blunt tip. The majority of rays touched or ran parallel to the y–1 axis, in some specimens (Figs 10a, b) the rays were angled in a posterior direction, extending past the y–1. In most cases a delicate ray apophysis was present and in some specimens the ray apophyses were slightly more prominent (Figs 10b, c). The ray connections of the examined specimens were either marginally narrower than the width of the rest of the ray or of equal thickness of the ray. The ratio of the denticle above and below the x axis fell in a range between 0.5 and a maximum of 0.74, with most of the ranges clustering around 0.54.

Remarks. All tadpole trichodinid populations presented by Arthur and Lom (1984), Kruger et al. (1993a), Dias et al. (2009), Pala et al. (2018) and the populations from the current study show similarities in the biometrical data (Tables 4 and 5) and denticle shape (Figs 10 and 11). All of the above-mentioned populations represent the same species and based on the comparative similarities the denticle plan of this typical tadpole trichodinid is as follows:

Rays are always delicate and of equal thickness throughout the length of the ray.

Ray connections are thin, of the same thickness or slightly narrower than the rest of the ray.

Rays all terminate in rounded points.

The y axes’ relationship to the rays vary from touching the complete proximal side of the ray (Figs 11c, d, f) to running parallel, but not touching the ray (Figs 10 c, e, f; 11a, b, e). Variation noted in some individuals of the Botswana population includes rays angled posteriorly where some cross the y axes (Figs 10a,b) and angled anteriorly where some touch the y axes (Fig. 10e). However in all cases, the ray connection and base of the ray never cross the y axes posteriorly.

The central parts of all these trichodinid populations are narrow, elongated and of equal width throughout.

The base of the central part is of the same width as the central part for all populations. Posterior projections are observed in the population described by Pala et al. (2018) (Figs 11e, f), however, the above mentioned characteristics for the central part still apply.

The posterior termination of the central part is distinctly rounded.

In the majority of cases, bar the population of Kruger et al. (1993a) (Fig. 11c) the central part leans in a proximal direction.

In contrast, the typical denticle plan for T. hypsilepis from fish hosts is as follows:

Rays are always robust and never of equal thickness throughout the length of the ray (Figs 12a–f).

Ray connections vary from broad, narrowing after the connection (Figs 12a, c, f) and ray connection is well developed, but still narrower than the base of the ray (Figs 12b, e). Both of these characteristics can sometimes be observed in the same individual, but in different denticles (Fig. 12d).

Rays all narrow perceptibly along their length ending in a narrow/sharp point.

The y axes’ relationship to the rays vary from touching the complete proximal side of the ray (Figs 12b, c, f), running parallel, but not touching the ray (Figs 12a, d); to running though the midsection of the ray (Fig. 12e). Again, these characteristics can vary in different denticles of the same individual (Figs 12d, e, f).

The central parts of all T. hypsilepis populations are squat, varying in shape.

The base of the central part is always significantly wider than the central part proper.

The central part in the majority of cases is triangular.

In the majority of cases, bar the population of Pala et al. (2018) (Fig. 12e) the central part exhibits no slant.
